bullets.text: U.S.–Iran Geneva talks reported “good progress,” while Iran partially restricts the Strait of Hormuz, raising oil-supply risk even as prices dip on diplomacy hopes.
Trump leans on informal envoys over State Department capacity, potentially reducing institutional leverage and increasing policy volatility in negotiations with rivals and allies.
Ukraine war remains difficult to end quickly; entrenched battlefield realities and Russian objectives constrain near-term settlement odds and keep European security risk elevated.
Japan trade strength: exports jump ~17% in January, boosted by China demand; underscores uneven global growth as some regions rebound while others slow.
Trump highlights initial Japanese commitments to invest in the U.S., signaling industrial-policy competition for capital and supply-chain localization.
U.S. DHS funding impasse drags on; shutdown risk adds fiscal and operational uncertainty, potentially disrupting travel, security programs, and contractor cashflows.
Wealth-tax politics intensify: New York threatens large property-tax hikes absent new levy; California opposition mobilizes ahead of high-profile support.
Cybersecurity growth jitters: Palo Alto Networks stock drops on underwhelming outlook, showing AI narrative can’t offset guidance pressure and valuation sensitivity.
AI capex arms race: Meta expands Nvidia partnership to deploy millions of chips; reinforces data-center bottlenecks (power, memory) and supports semiconductor demand.
Big Tech volatility: Amazon snaps steep losing streak after ~$450B market-cap drawdown, highlighting sensitivity to growth expectations and rates-driven discounting.
Berkshire shifts: trims Apple, adds New York Times; signals portfolio de-risking from mega-cap concentration and a tilt toward cashflowing, defensible franchises.
AI model pace accelerates with Anthropic’s Claude Sonnet 4.6, but surveys suggest limited productivity and employment impact so far—supporting an “AI adoption lag” thesis.
Healthcare science: new blood tests and RNA findings aim to detect cancer earlier; potential to reshape screening markets but requires validation, cost-effectiveness, and regulatory clearance.
Quantum advances and risks: Majorana-qubit progress contrasts with identified vulnerabilities that could undermine quantum encryption, emphasizing security-by-design for future communications.
